docs.lead_paragraph: There is the odd hole-in-the-wall serving up fiery jerk chicken, or a greengrocer with 10 kinds of exotic yams on his shelves. Cricket matches can be glimpsed in Van Cortlandt Park on summer afternoons. But it is difficult to identify overt signs of West Indian culture among the neatly kept, modest brick houses of Williamsbridge and Wakefield. Yet these northeastern Bronx neighborhoods are home to one of the largest concentrations of Jamaicans in the city, with Crown Heights and East Flatbush, Brooklyn. And they are the literal descendants of the close-knit, sociable and striving community of Jamaican immigrants in the Bronx that nurtured retired Gen. Colin L. Powell and launched him on his career.

headline.main: A Jamaican Way Station in the Bronx;Community of Striving Immigrants Fosters Middle-Class Values

headline.main: Inco Ltd.(N,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Sep 30

docs.lead_paragraph: An axiom of the welfare debate holds that the way out of poverty is a job, and no state has put more of its poor into jobs than Michigan. Three years after the Governor, John Engler, began recasting the welfare system in his conservative Republican vision, his program is being cited as a model by Congressional Republicans, who are putting the final touches on legislation that would upend Federal antipoverty policy. Governor Engler and his social services director, Gerald H. Miller, were influential lobbyists to Congress in shaping the legislation, which would slash up to $100 billion of Federal aid for the poor and give states block grants to run welfare programs of their own design.

headline.main: Michigan Puts Poor to Work But Gains Appear Precarious

docs.lead_paragraph: The Zenith National Insurance Corporation said yesterday that it had dropped plans to develop a managed-care company with U.S. Healthcare Inc. and the Unum Corporation because it could not reach terms with U.S. Healthcare. The venture had intended to market regular managed health care coverage in a package with workers' compensation and disability insurance coverage. U.S. Healthcare, based in Blue Bell, Pa., is a managed-care company. The other two companies are insurance providers. Zenith National, based in Woodland Hills, Calif., said it would expand an alliance with Unum in California and other areas. Unum is based in Portland, Me.

headline.main: ZENITH NATIONAL DROPS PLAN FOR MANAGED-CARE VENTURE

docs.lead_paragraph: The Republican Mayor of New York City dropped by the hotel suite of the Democratic President of the United States last night, and any political divisions between the two men quickly evaporated in an agreement on the dangers posed to the city by the Republican plan to cut the Medicare and Medicaid programs. In a half-hour visit at the Waldorf-Astoria, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani urged President Clinton to veto the plan recently passed by the House to cut $270 billion from Medicare and $187 billion from Medicaid. After the meeting, the Mayor told reporters that the President, who has already threatened to veto the bill, hopes he will not have to do so.

headline.main: Giuliani and Clinton Assess Perils in Cuts for Medicare

docs.lead_paragraph: More than a dozen insurance companies have agreed to offer information and services at a central site on the Internet's World Wide Web. The agreement, which was announced yesterday, raises the possibility that a central Internet site may evolve where consumers can get information and shop for a wide range of policies, without having to communicate with each company separately.

headline.main: Insurers Join a Common Web Site, Allowing Consumers to Compare

docs.lead_paragraph: It sounds like a Halloween fable, but a number of reputable psychiatrists and psychologists, specialists in the increasingly popular ailment of multiple personality disorder, maintain that some of their patients have been programmed by satanic cults to torture, murder and cannibalize. These unfortunates have been institutionalized for long periods, given heavy doses of drugs and questioned relentlessly to extract hidden memories of what the cults did to them. The existence of such cults, though advertised in church sermons and on television talk shows, has yet to be detected by the F.B.I. The impression left by "The Search for Satan" is that the doctors are the torturers and the patients are the ones being tortured.

headline.main: Who Programmed Mary? Could It Be Satan?

docs.lead_paragraph: Lobbyists for the elderly, for disabled people, for doctors, hospitals, drug companies and all sorts of health care providers descended on Capitol Hill today for an all-out effort to influence legislation on Medicare and Medicaid. They were the vanguard of an army of lobbyists working overtime as the Senate and the House prepared to vote on budget proposals affecting almost every household and industry in the country.

docs.lead_paragraph: Sometimes with the tacit support of party leaders and sometimes in defiance of them, moderate Republicans are making headway in promoting centrist compromises in Congress on important environmental issues. This month, they have pressed proposals on the Federal cleanup of toxic-waste dumps, municipal drinking water standards, wildlife preservation and commercial fishing controls. They say their goals are twofold: to enact legislation that can become law, instead of being vetoed, and to quell widespread criticism that the party is indifferent to the environment and in thrall to corporate polluters.

headline.main: Moderates Soften G.O.P. Agenda on Environment

docs.lead_paragraph: A stroke felled Michelangelo Antonioni in 1985, leaving him virtually unable to speak. In the years that followed, Mr. Antonioni, one of the world's most innovative and enigmatic film makers, sank into despair. "He once said, 'To direct is to live,' " his wife, Enrica Antonioni, said during a recent conversation in a suite at the Sunset Marquis Hotel in West Hollywood. "After the stroke, he was so bored, so unhappy. He's a man of enormous energy, and there was nothing for him but emptiness."
